Graphical abstract This work reports new findings on the oxidation chemistry of few-layer Ti3C2T x (MXene) sheets in aqueous solution and their effect on the electrocatalytic properties for hydrogen evolution reaction. Transition metal carbides and nitrides (MXenes) nanosheets are attractive two-dimensional (2D) materials, but they suffer from oxidation/degradation issues during storage and/or applications due to their sensitivity to water and oxygen. Despite the great research progress, the exact oxidation kinetics of Ti3C2T x (MXene) and their final products after oxidation are not fully understood. Herein, we systematically tracked the oxidation process of few-layer Ti3C2T x nanosheets in an aqueous solution at room temperature over several weeks. We also studied the oxidation effects on the electrocatalytic properties of Ti3C2T x for hydrogen evolution reaction and found that the overpotential to achieve a current density of 10 mA cm− 2 increases from 0.435 to 0.877 V after three weeks of degradation, followed by improvement to stabilized values of around 0.40 V after eight weeks. These results suggest that severely oxidized MXene could be a promising candidate for designing efficient catalysts. According to our detailed experimental characterization and theoretical calculations, unlike previous studies, black titanium oxide is formed as the final product in addition to white Ti (IV) oxide and disordered carbons after the complete oxidation of Ti3C2T x . This work presents significant advancements in better understanding of 2D Ti3C2T x (MXene) oxidation and enhances the prospects of this material for various applications. Keywords 2D materials MXene Chemical degradation Catalysis Hydrogen evolution reaction 1 Introduction Two-dimensional (2D) layered structures are a class of new materials that exhibit exciting prospects for various applications [1,2]. A classic example is graphene with atomically thin sheets of carbon structurally arranged like chicken wire [3]. Meanwhile, transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) are semiconductors with a direct bandgap due to quantum confinement [4,5]. Furthermore, elemental 2D materials such as phosphorene and antimonene possess highly tunable bandgaps just by adjusting the number of layers, making them attractive for various applications [6]. In 2011, transition metal carbides, carbonitrides, and nitrides with the general formula M n +1X n T x (M represents transition metals such as Ti, V, Nb, and Mo; X is C and/or N, T x expresses termination groups such as –OH, =O, and –F) have been introduced as MXene to the family of 2D materials [7]. In general, MXenes are synthesized by a wet-chemical method from ceramic M n +1AX n phases (MAX, A is an A-group element such as Al, Si, Ga, etc.) [7,8]. Ti3C2T x is the most widely used MXene and exhibits attractive chemical, optical, physical, and mechanical properties including excellent conductivity, high surface area, and good optical transparency [9–14]. These fascinating properties make MXene nanosheets attractive for a wide range of applications such as energy storage [15], sensing technology [16,17], electromagnetic interference shielding [18,19], membranes [20–23], catalysis [24,25], optoelectronics [26,27], and photovoltaics [28]. MXenes are composed of stacked metallic-like ultrathin sheets held together by the termination groups, making them strongly hydrophilic and thus dispersible in a range of common solvents for further storage and/or applications. However, 2D Ti3C2T x flakes tend to be oxidized gradually in moist air and/or water, thus altering their fundamental properties. This issue has led to considerable efforts focusing on exploring the oxidation kinetics of Ti3C2T x (MXene) under various experimental conditions. For example, Zhang et al. [29] reported that Ti3C2T x -water solutions in open vials were degraded completely after 15 days, leading to the formation of a colloidal solution containing anatase TiO2 and disordered carbons. Green and colleagues examined the oxidation of Ti3C2T x in various media via conductivity measurements [30]. They found that the conductivity decreases when Ti3C2T x ages in an aqueous solvent; ultraviolet (UV) light exposure accelerates the oxidation. In recent studies, Koo’s group studied the oxidation reactions of Ti3C2T x based aqueous solutions at different pH and temperatures [31,32]. The majority of these studies consistently reported that the degradation of Ti3C2T x in water leads to the formation of TiO2 and disordered graphitic or amorphous carbons, while suggesting different gaseous species such as CH4, CO, CO2, and HF are produced [29–34]. Although there are numerous studies on improving the stability of Ti3C2T x by monitoring storage conditions or passivation [33,34], it is extremely important to understand the exact mechanism and other related kinetics to advance this field. Despite many interesting studies, the oxidation mechanism of Ti3C2T x (MXene) flakes and their final products after complete oxidation require detailed investigations to provide more accurate and reliable knowledge. Herein, we systematically tracked the oxidation of Ti3C2T x in aqueous solutions in ambient conditions to elucidate the detailed mechanism and to reveal the final products after complete oxidation. To provide guidance for designing novel catalysts based on 2D MXene, we carefully investigated the oxidation effects on the electrocatalytic performance of Ti3C2T x for the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). A combination of detailed experimental investigations and theoretical calculations revealed that white Ti (IV) oxide, black titanium oxide, and disordered carbon are formed as the final products after the complete oxidation of Ti3C2T x that was sitting in aqueous solution for several months. Notably, the formation of a key product, namely black titanium oxide, was not realized in previous studies. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of Ti3C2Tx (MXene) 2D Ti3C2T x nanosheets were synthesized by etching Ti3AlC2 (MAX; Sigma Aldrich) phases using a hydrofluoric acid (HF) according to well established protocols [35]. Briefly, MAX powder (2.5 g) was added to 25 mL aqueous HF (10%, XiLong Chemistry), followed by stirring for 18 h at room temperature. After the etching process, the mixture was washed with deionized (DI) water and centrifuged until reaching pH value up to 5–6. It should be noted that this procedure was repeated 12 times. The collected pellet was redispersed in 25 mL dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO) and stirred for 24 h at room temperature for intercalation process. After DMSO was removed by centrifugation, the sample was mixed with DI water and sonicated for 1 h to obtain homogenous dispersion of Ti3C2T x in water. Then, the dispersion was centrifuged at 100× g for 30 min (two cycles) to remove any unetched MAX phase and the thick MXene flakes. 2.2 Oxidation of Ti3C2Tx (MXene) MXene nanosheets were dispersed and stored in DI water in ambient conditions. No degassing and/or any other treatments were applied to the dispersion. The initial concentration of the dispersion was 0.32 mg mL−1 and the sample was stored in ambient conditions (20 °C temperature and in dark condition). Notably, a previous study has demonstrated the acceleration of oxidation under exposure to UV light [30]. The dispersion was gently shaken for a very short time prior to each measurement. UV-vis spectroscopy measurements of the solution samples were taken daily for several weeks. For other measurements, the samples were prepared from the oxidized MXene dispersions on preferred substrates. For comparison, for tracking the oxidation of thin films in ambient conditions, Ti3C2T x aqueous dispersion was first deposited on the substrate and stored in air at room temperature for several weeks. 2.3 Materials characterization UV-vis spectra were recorded on UV-vis spectrophotometer (UV-vis Cary 60). For X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis, the samples were scanned at a fixed sample illumination mode (5 mm illumination length), and the data were collected on a MAXima-X XRD-7000 diffractometer. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) scans were obtained using a Kratos Axis ULTRA X-ray photoelectron spectrometer incorporating a 165 mm hemispherical electron energy analyzer. The incident radiation was monochromatic Al K α X-ray (1486.6 eV) at 225 W (15 kV, 15 mA). Survey scans were carried out at binding energies between 1200 and 0 eV with an interval of 1.0 eV and a dwell time of 100 ms, while high resolution (HR) scans were conducted with 0.05 eV steps and 250 ms dwell time. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) imaging and energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) mapping were acquired using a FEI Titan Themis. The scanning transmission electron microscope (STEM) probe was aberration-corrected, enabling sub-Angstrom spatial resolution, and high-angle annular dark-field (HAADF) STEM images were obtained. Raman spectra were acquired using a WITec alpha300 RA + S Raman microscope at an excitation laser wavelength of 532 nm. 2.4 Electrochemical measurements All the electrochemical measurements were carried out on an electrochemical workstation (DY2311) in a standard three-electrode system with 0.5 M H2SO4 electrolyte at room temperature. Ag/AgCl (3 M KCl) electrode and platinum wire were used as the reference electrode and counter electrode, respectively. The working electrode was prepared from the dispersion of 5 mg catalyst in 1 mL mixture of water (800 µL)/isopropanol (200 µL) with the addition of 50 µL Nafion solution (5 wt%). Then the as-prepared catalyst ink was loaded onto a glassy carbon (GC) electrode. The catalyst loading was 0.708 mg cm−2. Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) was carried out at a scan rate of 50 mV s−1 with an interval of 1 mV. The potentials obtained against an Ag/AgCl electrode were converted to a reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) using the Nernst formula, E RHE = E Ag/AgCl + 0.196 V + 0.0591pH. 2.5 Theoretical calculations Density-functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed using the projector augmented wave (PAW) pseudopotential method [36], as implemented in the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) [37]. Exchange and correlation interactions between electrons were described with the generalized gradient approximation formulated by Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) [38]. A 3 × 3 supercell (72 atoms) with a large vacuum region of 15 Å along the perpendicular direction was used. Lattice and atomic positions were fully relaxed until the residual forces became smaller than 10−5 eV Å−1. A kinetic energy cutoff of 500 eV was used for the plane-wave basis. 5 × 5 k-point mesh was used for integration over the 2D Brillouin zone (BZ) for the 3 × 3 supercell. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of Ti3C2Tx sheets 2D Ti3C2T x nanosheets were prepared by etching Ti3AlC2 (MAX) phase using a HF according to an established protocol [35]. Fig. 1 (a) displays the schematic illustration of the synthesis of few-layer Ti3C2T x nanosheets. After the etching process, delamination of Ti3C2T x powder was achieved by introducing DMSO solvent. The as-synthesized Ti3C2T x aqueous dispersion was characterized using a UV-vis spectroscopy (Fig. 1b) and showed three peaks at wavelengths of 260, 320, and 805 nm, while no noticeable peak was observed for the Ti3AlC2 (MAX). While the peaks at wavelengths of 260 and 320 nm are the characteristic peaks for fresh Ti3C2T x solutions [28,39], the peak at 805 nm was observed due to the plasmonic properties of the Ti3C2T x nanosheets [40]. As illustrated in Fig. 1(c), the XRD pattern of Ti3AlC2 shows peaks at around 9.5° (002), 19.1° (004), 34.0° (101), 39.0° (104), 41.7° (105), 48.4° (107), 56.3° (109), and 60.1° (110) [41]. The disappearance of these peaks with exception of (002) plane after HF etching suggests the successful removal of aluminum (Al) from the MAX phase. The (002) peak shifting from 9.5° to 6.6° implies increased d-spacing of Ti3C2T x due to the delamination and termination groups introduced during the etching process [28]. XPS survey scans of Ti3C2T x nanosheets confirm the existence of all expected elements (Ti, C, O, and F) in the sample (Fig. S1). As shown in Fig. 1(d), HR Ti 2p XPS spectrum of Ti3C2T x nanosheets displays two wide peaks, which can be deconvoluted into three main spin-orbit split doublets with a splitting of ∼5.50 eV. The deconvoluted peaks can be assigned to the Ti–C bonding at a binding energy of ∼455 eV, Ti (II) suboxide/hydroxides at ∼457 eV, and Ti (III) suboxides/hydroxides at ∼458 eV. In the C 1s core-level XPS spectrum (Fig. 1e), the appearance of a strong peak at a binding energy of 282 eV further confirms the Ti–C bonding in the sample, demonstrating the successful synthesis of Ti3C2T x . 3.2 Oxidation and catalytic properties of Ti3C2Tx (MXene) The oxidation of the aqueous Ti3C2T x dispersion was tracked in ambient conditions using a UV-vis spectroscopy. No degassing and/or any other treatments were applied to the Ti3C2T x dispersion. UV-vis absorption was collected on the sample daily for more than a month. As shown in Fig. 2 (a), the three characteristic peaks (260, 320, and 805 nm) observed from the fresh Ti3C2T x solution (dark orange) start to change upon oxidation. The peak intensity of 320 nm peak gradually decreased over time, which was in agreement with literature [42]. Meanwhile, it was observed that the peak at 260 nm shifts to 302 nm during oxidation. Indeed, we paid particular attention to the absorbance peak at 805 nm and plotted its changes as a function of oxidation time in Fig. 2(b). The intensity of this peak (at 805 nm) gradually decreased with increasing storage time, indicating the progressive degradation of Ti3C2T x in water. In addition to the changes in the peak intensity, a slight redshift was observed in the wavelength range of >780 nm. This redshift is commonly observed in Ti3C2T x (MXene) due to the changes in the oxidation state of Ti in the sample [34]. Furthermore, we investigated the UV-vis absorbance of Ti3C2, Ti3C2 with different extents of oxidation (Ti3C2O1 and Ti3C2O2), and TiO2 using DFT calculations [38]. It should be noted that the average optical spectrum for the x- and y-directions was qualitatively similar; and as such, these calculations are performed with an incident polarization along the y-direction. We explored four different structures including Ti3C2, Ti3C2O1, Ti3C2O2, and TiO2, as depicted in Fig. S2. The absorption spectra of these structures are displayed in Fig. 2(c). In general, the absorption spectra of the Ti3C2O x (where x = 0, 1, or 2) structures are qualitatively consistent with the experimental spectra of MXene dispersions in terms of possessing characteristic peaks within the wavelength ranges of 200–400 nm and >700 nm. Specifically, besides the shifts observed in the UV-region (Fig. 2c), we can clearly observe from the theoretical spectra that the wide peak at the wavelengths >700 nm redshifts as we go from the pure Ti3C2 (without oxidation) to the oxidized structures. This is in excellent agreement with the redshift observed from the experimental measurements. These changes in the optical absorbance of Ti3C2T x (MXene) solutions are believed to have a direct relation with the electronic properties of the material. Therefore, we carried out density of states (DOS) calculations to reveal the electronic state densities of Ti3C2, Ti3C2O1, Ti3C2O2, and TiO2. As shown in Fig. 2(d), pure Ti3C2 exhibits a metallic character with zero bandgap, but it changes to a semiconductor after severe oxidation. The partial density of states (PDOS) calculations for individual atoms suggest that Ti atom on the surface plays the key role in changing the electronic properties of Ti3C2 owing to the changes of Ti oxidation states (Fig. S3) [34]. XPS was used to gain in-depth insights into the chemical composition of Ti3C2T x nanosheets during oxidation. It should be noted that the sample was stored in water solution in ambient conditions and was drop-casted onto a silicon (Si) substrate right before the XPS characterization was conducted. Fig. 3 (a and b) displays the HR Ti 2p and C 1s XPS spectra of fresh and aged (over six weeks) Ti3C2T x sample. The HR Ti 2p spectra (Fig. 3a) show that the photoelectrons emitted from the orbitals of the Ti–C bond (orange arrow) decreased as the storage time increased. Notably, the spin-orbit split doublets with a splitting of 5.50 eV for Ti were consistent with the XPS handbook [43]. A pair of peaks (dark-green arrow) at binding energies of around 459 and 465 eV appeared in the second week of oxidation. These new peaks can be assigned to the characteristic peaks of Ti (IV) oxide [44], which is in agreement with our UV-vis spectrum of Ti3C2T x after oxidation (forming TiO2). Importantly, it can be observed from Fig. 3(a) that the Ti–O peak at around 459 eV started to widen and shifted to the lower binding energies from week 2 to week 6. This shift, while widening, is due to the formation of both Ti4+ and Ti3+. Meanwhile, as depicted in Fig. 3(b), the intensity of the C 1s peak at a binding energy of around 282 eV, which corresponds to Ti–C bond, decreased continuously during oxidation and completely disappeared after six weeks. For detailed assessment, deconvoluted core-level Ti 2p and C 1s XPS spectra are shown in Figs. S4 and S5, respectively. In addition, we briefly tracked the oxidation of Ti3C2T x thin films in ambient conditions (in air). In short, the Ti3C2T x was deposited on a silicon substrate after aging for only one week and stored in air at room temperature for several weeks. As displayed in Fig. S6(a), HR Ti 2p spectra of the first week sample (week 1) show small Ti–O peak at around 459 eV as it was oxidized in water solution during the first week of storage. Interestingly, unlike Ti3C2T x aqueous sample, no significant changes in the HR Ti 2p and C 1s spectra were observed in the thin film exposed to air (Fig. S6), demonstrating the better stability of Ti3C2T x thin film as compared to the aqueous dispersion. This also suggests that a combination of water and oxygen accelerates the oxidation of Ti3C2T x (MXene). Fig. 3(c) shows the TEM and HRTEM image of fresh Ti3C2T x sheets. HRTEM image of a typical Ti3C2T x was captured with a smooth surface and clean edge, revealing the obvious lattice spacing of ca. 0.26 nm [45]. The corresponding selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern demonstrates the high crystallinity of the Ti3C2T x nanosheets, as shown in the inset of HRTEM image in Fig. 3(c). After six weeks of degradation in the aqueous solution, the morphology and surface of the MXene flakes changed to be rough and damaged (Fig. 3d). As illustrated in the SAED pattern captured after six weeks of degradation (inset of HRTEM image in Fig. 3d), the crystal structure of the MXene changed to be amorphous or polycrystalline. Two sets of lattice fringes perpendicular to each other with spacing of 0.29 and 0.32 nm were observed (see HRTEM image in Fig. 3d). The distances can be assigned to the d spacings of (001) and (110) reflections of rutile TiO2 [46]. Fig. 3(e) depicts the HAADF-STEM and the corresponding EDX elemental mapping images of Ti3C2T x nanosheets before and after six weeks of degradation. It can be seen from the EDX elemental mapping that the fresh Ti3C2T x nanosheets have a relatively smooth surface with uniform distributions of Ti, O, and C atoms. However, we observed disordered distributions of these atoms in the sample after six weeks of degradation, indicating the structural cleavage of Ti3C2T x nanosheets. Specifically, as compared to the fresh Ti3C2T x , the oxidized sample showed a stronger signal of C atoms in the EDX elemental mapping image, revealing the formation of amorphous (disordered) carbon [47]. In addition, we also carried out EDX elemental mapping on Ti3C2T x aged for only one week in water solution and found that the nanosheets started to be oxidized from their edges (Fig. S7). Moreover, XRD analysis was conducted weekly on Ti3C2T x aqueous solution and patterns are displayed in Fig. S8(a). Clearly, the intensity of typical (002) peak (at 6°–7°) of Ti3C2T x slowly decreased over the oxidation period. Meanwhile, the appearance of many new peaks, which can be assigned to the characteristic peaks of oxidized Ti species, further confirms the accelerated oxidation of Ti3C2T x in water solution. Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) spectra of Ti3C2T x solution during oxidation over several weeks are depicted in Fig. S8(b). The only noticeable change was the peak intensity at around 640 cm−1 increasing from week 0 to week 6 due to the oxidation of Ti species. Although 2D structure is retained after severe oxidation (see scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images in Figs. S9 and S10), the formation of sub-nanoparticles can be observed after oxidizing for 8 weeks. The corresponding EDX elemental mapping suggests that these particles are mainly Ti and O. Furthermore, we investigated the influence of oxidation levels on the electrocatalytic properties of Ti3C2T x nanosheets for the HER in an acidic media (0.5 M H2SO4). Notably, 2D Ti3C2T x nanosheets have recently gained much interest in systems using advanced catalysis including HER [48]. In particular, MXene nanosheets have shown specific promise for developing efficient catalysts by acting as solid supporting materials for hosting catalytically active single metal atoms, clusters, and nanoparticles [25,49]. Therefore, understanding the exact role of chemical states in MXene nanosheets is of great importance for the development of high-performance catalyst materials. Fig. 4 (a) shows the LSV curves of glassy carbon (GC) electrode, Ti3AlC2 (MAX phase), fresh Ti3C2T x nanosheets, and Pt disk (d = 3 mm). The electrocatalytic performances of these catalyst electrodes can be compared based on the overpotential values required to achieve a current density of 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 4b) and Tafel slope measurement (Fig. 4c). It can be clearly seen from these measurements that both GC electrode and Ti3AlC2 are catalytically inactive for the HER in an acidic media, while the control Pt disk exhibits excellent performance with a Tafel slope of only 36.9 mV dec−1, which is consistent with the values reported for standard Pt/C catalyst in literature [50]. The measured overpotential (at 10 mA cm−2) and Tafel slope for the fresh Ti3C2T x nanosheets were 0.435 V and 139.0 mV dec−1, respectively, which are typical values for few-layer Ti3C2T x [51–53]. We also calculated the electrochemical double-layer capacitance (C dl) from the cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurements as a function of the scan rates (2–100 mV s−1). It is well known that the C dl is linearly proportional to the electrochemically active surface area of catalysts [54]. The C dl value of the Ti3C2T x was measured to be 0.95 mF cm−3 (Fig. S11). The LSV curves displayed in Fig. 4(d) showed interesting trends as a function of oxidation time. The overpotential values and Tafel slopes of the Ti3C2T x based electrodes during oxidation have been summarized in Fig. 4(e and f), respectively. The overpotential (at 10 mA cm−2) of the Ti3C2T x increased constantly from 0.435 to 0.877 V after three weeks of degradation, indicating the poor catalytic activity in mildly oxidized MXene. This catalytic degradation can be attributed to the reduced conductivity of Ti3C2T x after oxidation [30]. Interestingly, the catalytic performance started to improve slowly from week 4 until it stabilized at an overpotential value of around 0.40 V after eight weeks. It should be noted that this overpotential value achieved after eight weeks of oxidation is even better than that of the fresh Ti3C2T x catalyst. As shown in Fig. 4(f), the Tafel slopes recorded for the first six weeks (weeks 0–5) are significantly higher than those calculated for the last five weeks (weeks 6–10). Moreover, we carried out cyclic stability test on the fresh Ti3C2T x (denoted as week 0) and Ti3C2T x oxidized for eight weeks (week 8) by applying 500 continuous cycles (Fig. S12). Although no significant changes were observed before and after 500 CV cycles on both samples, the oxidized sample showed slightly better stability than the fresh Ti3C2T x . We finally computed the relative Gibbs free energy (ΔG H*) of an intermediate adsorbed H* to evaluate the HER and catalytic profile through a three-state reaction: (i) initial state H+ + e−, (ii) an intermediate adsorbed H*, and (iii) a final product 1/2H2. A highly efficient catalyst for the HER should have a near-zero value of ΔG H*. Our calculated ΔG H* of the initial product Ti3C2 (i) is −1.32 eV. This large value of ΔG H* indicates a strong chemical adsorption of H* on the Ti3C2 surface. However, it should be highlighted that Ti3C2 is only a theoretically designed structure, while the exact structure of fresh MXene contains various termination groups including oxygen, fluorine, and chlorine containing functional groups. The calculated values of ΔG H* for Ti3C2O x with different oxygen content (x = 0.0625–1.250) are depicted in Fig. S13. The ΔG H* value increases as x increases, reaching its maximum value of 0.14 eV at x = 1. The limited catalytic activity at low levels of oxidation is attributed to the reduced conductivity, as addressed experimentally in Fig. 4. Interestingly, the calculated ΔG H* decreases with further increase of x, and it changes sign to a negative value at x = 1.25, as shown in Fig. S13. This significant reduction in ΔG H* during oxidation suggests that the optimally oxidized MXene has a great potential as promising electrocatalysts. These theoretical calculations are qualitatively consistent with our experimental HER performances. 3.3 Post-oxidation and final products After complete oxidation of Ti3C2T x (MXene) nanosheets in aqueous solution (after >2 months), we observed the formation of two different phases (Fig. 5 a). To characterize the black and white colored products, the white dispersion was first separated from the black sediment via decantation. UV-vis spectra were recorded for both white and black samples (Fig. 5b). While the spectrum observed for the white sample was consistent with typical curve of TiO2-water solution [55], the black sample exhibited a curve similar to that of black titanium oxide reported in the literature [56]. Furthermore, it can be seen from Raman spectra (Fig. S14) that while no strong signals were detected for the white sample except for Si and SiO2 peaks at around 513 and 967 cm−1, respectively, the black solid showed several noticeable major peaks. Si and SiO2 peaks are expected as the samples were prepared on a Si substrate. Interestingly, as shown in the inset of Fig. S14, two major peaks at Raman shifts of 1300 and 1552 cm−1 were observed, corresponding to the disorder peak (D band) and graphitic peak (G band) of the carbon materials [57]. The D peak arises from the defects in the sp 2 carbon while the G band arises from the in-plane vibrational E 2g mode. The presence of both D and G bands in the Raman spectrum of our black sample obtained after post-oxidation confirms that amorphous carbon is one of the final products after the oxidation of Ti3C2T x (MXene), which is consistent with previous studies [29–34]. In addition to the stretching peak at 146.3 cm−1 for TiO2, the black sample also showed characteristic peaks at 268.4, 397.5, and 594.4 cm−1, which can be due to the presence of titanium oxycarbide (TiC x O y ) [58], indicating some incomplete oxidation. Moreover, Fig. S15 shows the XRD patterns of white and black residues obtained after Ti3C2T x oxidation. The major peak observed at 26.5° can be assigned to the (110) plane of rutile TiO2. It should be noted that the white and black samples were not completely separated due to the difficulties in processing. These results confirm the formation of rutile titanium oxide phase in the final products after complete oxidation of Ti3C2T x . Since it is not easy to distinguish the oxidation states of Ti in the sample using Raman spectroscopy, we used XPS analysis to gain further insight into the chemical states of the white and black samples. Fig. 5(c) compares the Ti 2p core-level XPS spectra of white and black solids obtained after complete oxidation of Ti3C2T x in aqueous solution. It can be clearly seen from Fig. 5(c) that the white solid showed the characteristic peak of Ti4+ compounds at a binding energy of around 459 eV, indicating the formation of Ti (IV) oxide in the final product. Meanwhile, the black solid exhibited the asymmetric peak of Ti3+ compounds located at a binding energy of around 458 eV, suggesting the presence of Ti3+ oxide after complete oxidation of Ti3C2T x . The O 1s XPS spectra displayed in Fig. 5(d) further confirm that Ti3+ compound is the key component in the black solid sample. The C 1s XPS spectra of the white and black phases are shown in Fig. S16. The absence of peaks at a binding energy of around 282 eV confirms that the carbide structure was broken. Overall, our experimental investigations reveal that the final products of Ti3C2T x (MXene) after complete oxidation in aqueous solutions are Ti (IV) oxide, black titanium oxide, and disordered carbon, all of which can be useful materials for various applications. For instance, Ti (IV) oxide holds specific promise for use in solar cells, catalysis, batteries, and others, while black titanium oxide has gained much interest in photocatalysis research [59]. Promisingly, this work demonstrates that these materials (Ti (IV) oxide, black titanium oxide, and carbon) can readily be obtained individually from the final product of Ti3C2T x after complete oxidation. Furthermore, we investigated the possibility for the formation of different oxidized species of Ti3C2 (MXene) using DFT calculations. Fig. 6 (a–e) shows the schematic illustration of the geometries for different compounds including (i) Ti3C2, (ii) Ti3C2O1, (iii) Ti3C2O2, (iv) formation of two possible oxidized species, and (v) final products containing two different Ti states (Ti3+ and Ti4+). Note that the presence of functional groups is fully disregarded in the present study for simplicity. As seen in Fig. 6(e), Ti-C compounds are produced in our final products after relaxation. These Ti-C compounds are expected to decompose after further oxidation, forming the very final product of disordered carbon species and more oxidized Ti species. Fig. 6(f) illustrates the relative formation energy diagram for these geometries and provides explanations for the formation of possible oxidized species from Ti3C2 (MXene). The formation energy is defined as E f = (E 0 − Σ iμiNi )N A/N, where E 0 is the total energy of the system and μi and Ni are the chemical potential and the number of decomposable component i, respectively. N A is the Avogadro's number and N is the total number of atoms in the computed unit cell. The formation energy of the initial structure (Ti3C2) is chosen as a reference energy 0 kJ mol−1 (stage i). The negative value of formation energy indicates the energetically favourable structure, and the more negative relative formation energy means high favorability of that structure from the previous one. The favored formation of Ti3C2O1 and Ti3C2O2 can be seen from the high negative relative formation energies calculated for these geometries. In line with the experimental observation, our calculations indicate that the oxidation occurs quickly owing to the higher formation energies of Ti3C2O1 (−68.4 kJ mol−1 in stage ii) and Ti3C2O2 (−125.4 kJ mol−1 in stage iii) relative to the initial product Ti3C2. Further oxidation tends to desorb the Ti atoms from the Ti3C2O2 layers underneath the surface oxygen upon adsorption of more oxygen (stage iv), leading to the simultaneous formation of Ti3+ and Ti4+ compounds as the final products (in stage v). This theoretical calculation is in excellent agreement with our experimental finding on the Ti3C2T x oxidation and its final products. It should be noted that although the formation energies for both Ti3+ and Ti4+ compounds were very close, the production of Ti4+ compound was slightly favorable. 4 Conclusions In summary, we have systematically studied the oxidation process of Ti3C2T x nanosheets in aqueous solution over several weeks. Meanwhile, we also tracked the catalytic performance of Ti3C2T x (MXene) as a function of oxidation rates for electrochemical H2 production in an acidic media. Interestingly, it was found that oxidized MXene shows great promise for designing efficient electrocatalysts, exhibiting the overpotential of around 0.40 V at 10 mA cm− 2 and Tafel slope of 108 mV dec−1. We revealed using both experimental investigations and theoretical calculations that the oxidation of Ti3C2T x (MXene) in aqueous solution leads to the formation of three different components as the final products, namely Ti (IV) oxide, black titanium oxide, and disordered carbon. Significantly, these different products can be collected and employed for various applications. This work presents great advancements in detailed understanding of 2D Ti3C2T x (MXene) and paves the way for employing this material for various applications. Particularly, research into designing novel catalysts by anchoring single metal atoms and nanoparticles onto oxidized MXene sheets would be of great interest. coredata.dc:description: Transition metal carbides and nitrides (MXenes) nanosheets are attractive two-dimensional (2D) materials, but they suffer from oxidation/degradation issues during storage and/or applications due to their sensitivity to water and oxygen. Despite the great research progress, the exact oxidation kinetics of Ti3C2T x (MXene) and their final products after oxidation are not fully understood. Herein, we systematically tracked the oxidation process of few-layer Ti3C2T x nanosheets in an aqueous solution at room temperature over several weeks. We also studied the oxidation effects on the electrocatalytic properties of Ti3C2T x for hydrogen evolution reaction and found that the overpotential to achieve a current density of 10 mA cm− 2 increases from 0.435 to 0.877 V after three weeks of degradation, followed by improvement to stabilized values of around 0.40 V after eight weeks. These results suggest that severely oxidized MXene could be a promising candidate for designing efficient catalysts. According to our detailed experimental characterization and theoretical calculations, unlike previous studies, black titanium oxide is formed as the final product in addition to white Ti (IV) oxide and disordered carbons after the complete oxidation of Ti3C2T x . This work presents significant advancements in better understanding of 2D Ti3C2T x (MXene) oxidation and enhances the prospects of this material for various applications.
